title: Improved Water Accessibility — 2SFCA
subtitle: Identifying households with low access to improved water sources in Sibi, Ghana using the Two-Step Floating Catchment Area method.
description: This analysis models spatial accessibility to improved water point sources (boreholes and public standpipes) in Sibi, Ghana by computing the ratio of available improved water point sources and households within 500m walking catchments.
methods: 500m catchments generated using OD Matrix — the 500m is Ghana's national standard for improved access
Key findings: Households at the peripheries have limited numbers of improved water sources leading to low accessibility scores.
Clusters of low access align with longer walking distances and lower facility density in these areas.
Results highlight priority areas for new or upgraded water points.

title: Flood Risk Mapping
subtitle: Hydrologic modeling using DEM, soil, and land cover to map susceptibility.
description: Flow direction, accumulation, and slope were combined with land cover and soils to produce a flood susceptibility index. Outputs support mitigation planning and infrastructure prioritization.

title: NDVI & Land Surface Temperature
subtitle: Vegetation–temperature dynamics to understand urban heat.
description: MODIS NDVI and LST time series were analyzed to reveal inverse relationships between greenness and temperature. Hotspots indicate where greening could reduce heat exposure.

title: Rainwater Harvesting Suitability
subtitle: Multi-criteria decision analysis for surface rainwater harvesting.
description: A weighted overlay of slope, roof area, rainfall, and proximity to buildings prioritizes locations for rainwater harvesting to enhance water security.

title: LiDAR Canopy Height Model
subtitle: Deriving DSM/DTM and CHM for urban greenness assessment.
description: LiDAR point clouds were processed to produce terrain and surface models. The canopy height model helps quantify vegetation structure and identify low-shade areas.
